questions.text: Most common type of epithelial ovarian tumors are:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Serous

  • 75-80% of epithelial cancers are serous histologic type
  • Classification of ovarian tumors: 

 

Educational Objective: 

  • The commonest type of ovarian cancer is epithelial ovarian cancer, amongst which, serous type is most common

 

Ref: Berek & novak 16 ed, page 2547

questions.text: A 25-year-old unmarried girl, whose mother died of ovarian cancer comes to you for advice regarding prevention of ovarian cancer. Which of the following will you suggest her for prevention of ovarian cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Oral contraceptive pill

  • OCP is the only documented method of chemoprevention for prevention of ovarian cancer.

Other Options: 

  • Option A and B: Salpingooophorectomy and mastectomy are advisable after genetic testing in women with strong family history of ovariana and breast cancer. Also as she is unmarried, doing a salpingectomy now would not be a suitable surgery as she might want to concieve in the future. 
  • Option C: HPV vaccine prevents cervical cancer.

Educational Objective: 

Risk Factors for epithelial ovarian cancer

  • Nulliparity
  • Early menarche, late menopause
  • White race
  • Increasing age
  • Family history
  • Personal h/o breast cancer
  • Ethnicity (European jews, Icelandic and Hungarian)
  • Post menopausal HRT
  • PID

Protective Factors for Ovarian cancer

  • B/l salpingectomy or tubal ligation
  • Oophorectomy
  • Combined OCP
  • Pregnancy and breast feeding

 

Ref: berek and noval 16 edition, page 2561

choices.text: Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are associated with increased risk of ovarian cancer
Hereditary cancer tends to occur in women 10 years earlier than the non-hereditary ovarian cancers
Most BRCA related ovarian cancers are high grade mucinous cancers
Prophylactic salpingo oophorectomy reduces risk of BRCA related gynecological cancer by 95%

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE regarding BRCA related hereditary ovarian cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Most BRCA related ovarian cancers are high grade mucinous cancers

 

  • Most BRCA related ovarian cancers are high grade serous cancers
  • Offer risk reducing bilateral salpingooophoerctomy to patients with BRCA 1 mutation at 35-40 years and BRCA 2 mutation by 40-45 years

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A: Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are associated with increased risk of ovarian cancer

 

  • The BRCA1 gene is located on chromosome 17q21. Patients with a proven mutation have a dramatically elevated risk of developing ovarian cancer (About 40%).
  • BRCA2 is located on chromosome 13q12 and in general is less likely to lead to ovarian cancer (12 to 20%).
  • The estimated lifetime risk of breast cancer with a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation is 65 - 74 percent

 

Option B: Hereditary cancer tends to occur in women 10 years earlier than the non-hereditary ovarian cancers. This is a correct statement

 

Option D: Prophylactic salpingo oophorectomy reduces risk of BRCA related gynecological cancer by 95% and should be done once a woman who is BRCA positive, her family is complete. The only proven way to directly prevent ovarian cancer is surgical removal. In BRCA1 or BRCA2 carriers, prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO) may be performed either upon completion of childbearing or by age 40 years

 

BRCA-Related Ovarian Cancer 

 

  • BRCA genes (BRCA1 & BRCA2) are tumor suppressor genes involved in DNA repair via homologous recombination.
  • Germline mutations in BRCA1 or BRCA2 increase the risk of high-grade serous epithelial ovarian cancer (HGSOC).

 

Diagnosis

 

  • All patients with epithelial ovarian cancer are advised to undergo genetic testing for BRCA mutations, regardless of age or family history.
  • Testing includes:
    • Germline BRCA1/2
    • Somatic BRCA testing (from tumor tissue)

 

Prognosis

 

  • BRCA-associated cancers have better initial response to platinum-based chemotherapy.
  • Improved progression-free survival and overall survival, especially with BRCA2.

 

Targeted Therapy

 

  • PARP inhibitors (e.g., olaparib, niraparib):
    • Exploit synthetic lethality in BRCA-deficient cells
    • Used as maintenance therapy post-chemotherapy or in recurrent disease
    • Most effective in BRCA-mutated and homologous recombination deficient (HRD) tumors

 

Prevention

 

  • Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy:
    • Recommended at 35–40 years (BRCA1) or 40–45 years (BRCA2)

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The BRCA genes increase the risk of serous epithelial ovarian cancers and breast cancers
  • BRCA1 gene is located on chromosome 17q21. Patients with a proven mutation have a dramatically elevated risk of developing ovarian cancer (About 40%).
  • BRCA2 is located on chromosome 13q12 and in general is less likely to lead to ovarian cancer (12 to 20%).
  • The estimated lifetime risk of breast cancer with a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation is 65 - 74 percent
  • The only proven way to directly prevent ovarian cancer is surgical removal.
  • In BRCA1 or BRCA2 carriers, prophylactic bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy (BSO) may be performed either upon completion of childbearing or by age 40 years

 

Ref: Berek and Novak 16 edition, pg 2566, Page 738, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Stage of the disease is I C3
The surgery is staging laparotomy with bilateral salpingectomy with omentectomy with pelvic and paraaortic lymphadenectomy
Post operative chemotherapy will be required

questions.text: A 50-year-old postmenopausal woman underwent staging laparotomy for ovarian malignancy. Intraoperatively, there was ascites present, 10*10 cm right ovarian cyst with an intact capsule, which ruptured during surgery to reveal solid areas, omentum had a 3*3cm deposit. The rest of abdominal organs were normal on palpation. On histopathology, ascites showed malignant cells, ovaries had serous carcinoma and the omentum showed malignant cells. Lymph nodes were free of tumor cells. Which of the following is TRUE for the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Post operative chemotherapy will be required

 

  • As per the FIGO staging for ovarian carcinoma (which is a surgical staging), she has stage IIIc disease. as she has an abdominal deposit (omental deposit) of 3 cm
  • lymph nodes are negative, there is no evidence of organ metastasis.
  • The FIGO staging is shown below
  • The primary mode of treatment of ovarian cancer is SURGICAL STAGING (which involves removing the uterus and ovaries with debulking of tumor tissue) followed by CHEMOTHERAPY (Platinum based - Cisplatin or Carboplatin  + Paclitaxel)

 

FIGO Staging of ovarian cancer

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A: Stage of the disease is I C3: The Stage is stage 3 

 

Option B: The surgery for ovarian cancer is staging laparotomy with bilateral salpingectomy with omentectomy with pelvic and paraaortic lymphadenectomy: The surgery is staging laprotomy which includes Total abdominal hysterectomy with b/l salpingo-oophorectomy with pelvic and para-aortic LN dissection with omentectomy with optimal debulking of visible tumor tissue

 

Option D: 5 year survival is 70%: 

 

  • In ovarian cancer, 5-year survuval in Stage 1 is 90%, stage 2 is 70%, stage 3 is 40% and stage 4 is 20%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The primary mode of treatment of ovarian cancer is SURGICAL STAGING (which involves removing the uterus and
  • ovaries with debulking of tumor tissue) followed by CHEMOTHERAPY (Platinum based - Cisplatin or Carboplatin  + Paclitaxel)

 

 

Ref: Berek and novak 16 edition, 2577 (page 2619)

questions.text: A 52-year-old female has epithelial ovarian tumor which on evaluation has been found to be unresectable and planned for neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Which of the following is the most suitable drug/drug combination for her?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Carboplatin paclitaxel (CP)

  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is an option for patients with advanced ovarian cancer who have a low likelihood of optimal cytoreduction/high perioperative risk.
  • Carboplatin paclitaxel is the most commonly used chemotherapy for epithelial ovarian cancer.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A: BEP protocol (Bleomycin, Etoposide, Paclitaxel) is the chemotherapy of choice in germ cell tumors
  • Option C: EMACO is the chemotherapy given in high risk choriocarcinoma
  • Option D: Methotrexate is recommended in low risk choriocarcinoma

Educational Objective: 

  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy is an option for patients with advanced ovarian cancer who have a low likelihood of optimal cytoreduction/high perioperative risk.
  • Carboplatin paclitaxel is the most commonly used chemotherapy for epithelial ovarian cancer.

Ref: Berek and novak 16 edition, 2600-02

choices.text: She has clear cell epithelial ovarian tumor
LDH is likely to be increased
She will require completion surgery with total abdominal hysterectomy and salpingooophorectomy

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with adnexal mass and undergoes unilateral salpingooophorectomy. Histopathology shows large clear cells with abundant cytoplasm, large nuclei with fibrous septae containing lymphocytic infiltrate as shown. Which of the following statements is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. LDH is likely to be increased

She has dysgerminoma and hence LDH which is the tumor marker is likely to be increased

Other Options:

  • Option A:  clear cell epithelial ovarian tumor: Clear cell tumors on microscopy have low cuboidal, polyhedral, hobnail or flattened cells with uniform nuclear atypia, prominent nucleoli and variable mitotic activity
  • Option B: She will require completion surgery with total abdominal hysterectomy and salpingooophorectomy: Fertility sparing surgery is preferred. If opposite side is suspicious, biopsy can be taken and chemotherapy is given. 
  • Option D: These tumors are radioresistant: These tumors are highly radiosensitive and chemosensitive.

 

Educational Objective:

Dysgerminoma

  • Dysgerminoma is the commonest (30–40%) malignant germ cell tumor.
  • It arises from undifferentiated form of germ cells.
  • In 5%: Dysgenetic gonads so karyotype may be required
  • The counterpart of dysgerminoma in male is seminoma.
  • Majority (75%) of the tumors occur before the age of 30 years.
  • Tumor marker is LDH
  • Pathology: The shape is usually round or oval and is usually 5–15 cm in diameter; It is firm rubbery. It may be bilateral (10%). Cut section shows pink or yellow color.
  • Microscopic appearance: uniform large round cells,  arranged in cords or clumps with abundant clear cytoplasm. Nuclei are large, irregular and hyperchromatic with varying degree of mitosis. There is intense infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells in the fibrous septum. Malignant in > 50%
  • Clinical features:  not specific for the tumor.
  • Treatment:
    • Majority (75%) of dysgerminomas are confined to one ovary and are stage I at the time of diagnosis In a young patient where preservation of fertility is desired, laparotomy for surgical staging and unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is done.
    • If there is any suspicion of involvement to the other ovary, bisection of the contralateral ovary and excisional biopsy should be done.
    • The tumor is sensitive to both chemotherapy and radiotherapy. 
    • BEP (Bleomycin, Etoposide and Cisplatin), VBP (Vinbla-stin, Bleomycin and Cisplatin), VAC (Vincristine, Actinomycin and Cyclophosphamide) are the commonly used drugs for the germ cell tumors. 

Ref: Berek & novak, 16 ed, page 2624-33.

questions.text: Identify the tumor in which this HPE finding is likely?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Yolk sac tumor

This is a HPE showing Schiller Duval body with central vessel and mantle of endoderm whish is typically seen in Yolk sac tumor

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Granulosa cell tumor: Pathognomonic HPE image is Call Exner bodies. Coffee bean nuclei is also seen
  • Option B: Dysgerminoma: Fried egg appearance is seen in HPE
  • Option D: Dermoid: Cell lines of ectoderm, endoderm and mesoderm is seen

 

 

Ovarian Tumor Markers: 

 

 

 

Ref: Berek & novak, page 2640

questions.text: Identify the histopathological finding:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Call exner bodies

  • Call exner bodies are pathognomonic of granulosa cell tumors
  • They are arranged in small clusters or rosettes around central cavity, resembling a primordial follicle

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Schiller Duvall bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors and appear as shown

  • Option C: Psammoma body: These are seen in seous epithelial ovarian tumors and appear as shown: 

  • Option D: Leydig cells: Reinkes crystals are seen in sertoli leydig cell tumor

Ref: Berek & novak 16 ed, page 2648

questions.text: Identify the tumor in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Dermoid

  • This is the typical gross image of an ovarian dermoid (mature cystic teratoma)
  • It is recognized by the typical hair, teeth and sebacious material

Other Options

  • Option A: Granulosa cell tumor: The gross appearance is as shown and features include: 
    • Well circumscribed, predominantly solid; occasionally solid and cystic
    • Lobulated, yellow-tan or tan-white cut surface

  • Option B: Endometriotic cyst: This typocally has chocolate like material as its content

  • Option D: Yolk sac tumor:  Appear as solid gray-white with a gelatinous, myxoid, or mucoid appearance. Necrosis, cystic changes, and hemorrhage are often seen as shown

 

Educational Objective: 

This is the typical gross pathological image of an ovarian dermoid

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is diagnosed to have endometrial carcinoma on biopsy. She wishes to understand the high-risk factors for development of endometrial cancer. Which of the following is NOT a risk factor for development of endometrial carcinoma:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Multiparity

  • Unopposed Estrogen therapy is seen in scenarios like PCOS, estrogen secretinf tumors like granulosa cell tumor and HRT with only estrogen

Educational Objective: 

Risk Factors for endometrial cancer include

  • Nulliparity
  • Early menarche and late menopause
  • Obesity
  • DM
  • Tamoxifen
  • Atypical Endometrial hyperplasia
  • Unopposed estrogen exposure 
    • PCOS
    • Granulosa cell ovarian tumor
    • HRT with only estrogen
  • Genetic syndromes like Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and Cowden syndrome

 

Ref: Berek & Novak, 16 ed, page 2362

choices.text: Manual vacuum aspiration cannula
Pipelle endometrial aspiration cannula

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pipelle endometrial aspiration cannula

  • This is an office endometrial aspiration cannula available as many names like pipelle and the vibra aspirator
  • It is used to procure an endometrial aspirate as an OPD procedure as the cannula is so thin, it does not usually require cervical dilatation
  • This procedure is done in women with Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB)
  • The other ways to obtain an endometrial sample for HPE is by
    • Hysteroecopic guided endometrial biopsy (Gold standard)
    • Dilatation and curettage 

Other Options:

  • Option A: Karmans cannula: These are disposable plastic cannulas which are color coded dependng on their diameter and appear as shown below. They are used as aspiration cannulas which are attached to an manual vacuum aspirator and are used to aspirate products of conception. 

  • Option B: Manual Vacuum Aspirator. This is attached to the Karman cannula and the vauum created is used in suction evacuation to aspirate products of conception

  • Option D: Uterine Sound: This is a slightly curved metal instrument used to measure the length of the uterine cavity in procedures like a D&C or during insertion of an intra-uterine device

Educational Objective: 

An endometrial biopsy can be taken by

  • Hysteroscopy guided endometrial biopsy (Gold standard)
  • Dilatation and curettage
  • Office endometrial aspiration in the OPD 

 

Ref :  https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Frequency-of-Positive-Endometrial-Pipelle-Biopsies-Zaman-Jabeen/30747f41d85e5bbb4783e846377d979c77102785

choices.text: Endometrial aspiration cannula for endometrial sampling
Karman cannula for RPOC
Manual Vacuum aspiration for missed abortion
Suction evacuation for molar pregnancy

questions.text: What procedure is done with the given instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Endometrial aspiration cannula for endometrial sampling

 

  • This is an office endometrial aspiration cannula available as many names like pipelle and the vibra aspirator
  • It is used to procure an endometrial aspirate as an OPD procedure as the cannula is so thin, it does not usually require cervical dilatation
  • This procedure is done in women with Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB)
  • The other ways to obtain an endometrial sample for HPE is by
    • Hysteroecopic guided endometrial biopsy (Gold standard)
    • Dilatation and curettage

Other Options

  • Option B: Karman cannula for RPOC: These are disposable plastic cannulas which are color coded dependng on their diameter and appear as shown below. They are used as aspiration cannulas which are attached to an manual vacuum aspirator and are used to aspirate products of conception.

  • Option C: Manual Vacuum aspiration for missed abortion. A Manual Vacuum Aspiratior (MVA)  is attached to the Karman cannula and the vauum created is used in suction evacuation to aspirate products of conception

  • Option D: Suction evacuation for molar pregnancy: Suction evacuation for molar pregnancy is usually done by a manual vacuum aspiration syringe as shown above or with an electrical vacuum aspiration in which the Karmans cannula is attached to an electrical suction machine

Educational Objective: 

  • This is an office endometrial aspiration cannula available as many names like pipelle and the vibra aspirator
  • It is used to procure an endometrial aspirate as an OPD procedure as the cannula is so thin, it does not usually require cervical dilatation
  • This procedure is done in women with Abnormal Uterine Bleeding (AUB)
  • The other ways to obtain an endometrial sample for HPE is by
    • Hysteroecopic guided endometrial biopsy (Gold standard)
    • Dilatation and curettage

 

Ref: https://www.semanticscholar.org/paper/Office-endometrial-sampling%3A-a-comparison-between-4-Zutshi-Gupta/25eacdc961e0fae8cb8414abee5961eed481c2f0

choices.text: Retained product of conception

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman visits OPD with heavy menstrual bleeding. Her USG is shown below Histopathology shows dilated cystic glands with increased gland: stroma ratio. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endometrial hyperplasia

  • Endometrial hyperplasia is a condition where there is endometrial thickening. It can be simple pr complex and with or without atypia.
  • Simple hyperplasia is characterized by dilated or cystic glands with round to slightly irregular shapes, an increased glandular-to-stromal ratio without glandular crowding
  • Complex hyperplasia has architecturally complex (budding and infolding) crowded glands, with less intervering stroma
  • Atypical hyperplasia refers to cytologic atypia and is a high risk for endometrial carcinoma

Other Options

  1. Option A: Endometrial cancer: In this the HPE will show features of carcinoma including  cellular / nuclear enlargement, nuclear rounding with large nucleoli, loss of polarity and cytoplasmic eosinophilia
  2. Option C: Molar Pregnancy: The USG image will show snowstorm appearance and the HPE will show, trophoblastic hyperplasia and villous edema
  3. Option D: Retained products of conception: This will appear as trophoblastic tissue on microscopy

Educational Objective: 

  • Endometrial hyperplasia is a condition where there is endometrial thickening. It can be simple pr complex and with or without atypia.
  • Simple hyperplasia is characterized by dilated or cystic glands with round to slightly irregular shapes, an increased glandular-to-stromal ratio without glandular crowding
  • Complex hyperplasia has architecturally complex (budding and infolding) crowded glands, with less intervering stroma
  • Atypical hyperplasia refers to cytologic atypia and is a high risk for endometrial carcinoma

 

Ref: berek & novak, 16 ed, page 2364

choices.text: Endometrial aspiration biopsy
Prepare for hysterectomy

questions.text: 55-year-old post-menopausal woman presents to OPD with post-menopausal bleeding. Her USG shows endometrial thickness of 7mm. Next step in management is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endometrial aspiration biopsy

  • After physical and pelvic examination, the first test to evaluate for signs of endometrial cancer is transvaginal ultrasound
  • If the endometrial thickness in a post menopausal woman is ≥ 5mm, an endometrial biopsy should be done. 
  • An endometrial biopsy can be obtained by
    • Office endomtrial aspiration
    • Dilatation and curettage
    • Hysteroscopy and biopsy (Gold standard)

Other Options: 

  • Option A: CA 125: This is a marker for epithelial ovarian cancer
  • Option C: Pap smear: This is a screening test for cervical cancer. In the queston it is already mentioned that the endometrium is thickened so taking a pap smear will not be the net best step
  • Option D: Prepare for a hysterectomy: Am endometrial biopsy is required an only if there is endometrial hyperplasia with atypia or if ther eis endometrial carcinoma, should a hysterectomy be done

Educational Objective: 

  • After physical and pelvic examination, the first test to evaluate for signs of endometrial cancer is transvaginal ultrasound
  • If the endometrial thickness in a post menopausal woman is ≥ 5mm, an endometrial biopsy should be done. 
  • An endometrial biopsy can be obtained by
    • Office endomtrial aspiration
    • Dilatation and curettage
    • Hysteroscopy and biopsy (Gold standard)

 

Ref: figo cancer report, 2021

choices.text: Ovaries should be conserved
Ovaries should be removed
Ovaries can be removed if they appear pathological
Ovaries should be conserved if patient is pre-menopausal and should be removed if patient is post-menopausal

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman with biopsy proven endometrial cancer and MRI showing endometrial growth involving more than 50% myometrium is undergoing hysterectomy. What will be your advice regarding removal of ovaries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ovaries should be removed

  • This patient probably has an endometrial cancer which has infilterated into the myometrium
  • The recommended standard surgical procedure is an extra-fascial total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.
  • Adnexal removal is recommended even if the tubes and ovaries appear normal, as they may contain micrometastases.
  • In premenopausal women with low-grade, early-stage disease, ovarian preservation could be considered 
  • Vaginal cuff removal is not advised, nor is there any benefit from excising parametrial tissue in the usual case. 

 

Educational Objective: 

The recommended surgical procedure in endometrial cancer is an extra-fascial total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

Ref: Figo cancer report 2021

choices.text: The patient has stage IIIb disease
No further treatment required as lymphadenectomy already done
Lymphadenectomy in endometrial cancer helps in staging and guiding further management
The patient will require adjuvant vaginal brachytherappy

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman underwent hysterectomy with bilateral salpingooophorectomy with pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy for endometrial cancer. Histopathology confirms lymph node involvement.  Which of the following statements is correct:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lymphadenectomy in endometrial cancer helps in staging and guiding further management

  • The patient has stage IIIc disease as per FIGO staging and  she will require complete surgical resection (TAH + BSO with pelvic and para-aortic lymphadenectomy) followed by post operative adjuvant EBRT +/- chemotherapy
  • Lymphadenectomy is required for accurate staging and is considered a staging procedure. Its potential therapeutic benefits are mainly contribution to accurate indication for adjuvant therapy.
  • Most patients presenting with Stage III endometrial cancer are managed by complete surgical resection of all pelvic and/or nodal disease, followed by postoperative EBRT and/or chemotherapy.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: The patient has stage IIIb disease: involvement of pelvic and para-aortic lymoh node involvement means stage III-C
  • Option B: No further treatment required as lymphadenectomy already done: Treatment of endocmtrial canncer is surgery f/b radiotherapy or chemotherapy. Only in very early stages with log grade tumor (Stage 1A1) is surgery sufficient
  • Option D: The patient will require adjuvant vaginal brachytherappy: Folowing surgery for endomatrial cancer, radiotherapy is given as external beam radiotherapy (EBRT) and not brachytherapy

Educational Objective: 

Ref: Figo cancer report 2021

choices.text: Type I endometrial cancer: due to unopposed estrogen
Type I endometrial cancer: due to unopposed progesterone
Type II endometrial cancer: due to unopposed estrogen
Type II endometrial cancer: due to unopposed progesterone

questions.text: In relation to endometrial cancer which of the following is CORRECT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Type I endometrial cancer: due to unopposed estrogen

  • Endometrial cancer is of 2 types: Type 1 (endometroid) and type 2 (non endometroid)
  • Type I endometrial cancers occur in women with history of exposure to unopposed estrogen. Type II endometrial carcinoma are estrogen independent tumors.

Educational Objective: 

Ref: Berek & novak, 16 edition, page 2362

choices.text: Endometroid with squamous differenciation

questions.text: Which of the following type of endometrial cancer type has worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Serous

  • Serous carcinomas are hgh risk lesions. They are a type of type 2 (non endometrioid) endometrial cancers and are more aggressive and have worese prognosis complared to type 1 cancers. 

Educational Objective: 

Ref: Berek and novak, 16ed, page 2378

choices.text: Cervical and ovarian
Cervical and GTN
Endometrial and cervical
Endometrial and ovarian cancer

questions.text: Most common simultaneously occurring malignancies are:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Endometrial and ovarian

  • Synchronous endometrial and ovarian tumors are the most frequent simultaneously occurring genital tract malignancies.
  • Ovarian granulosa cell tumors are frequenctly associated with endometrial hyperplasia and cancer due to unpoosed estrogen exposure

Educational Objective: 

  • Synchronous endometrial and ovarian tumors are the most frequent simultaneously occurring genital tract malignancies.

 

Ref: Berek and novak, 16ed, page 2381
